ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about consumer and producer theory, as well as some interesting applications.
Basic microeconomics skills.
I learned the importance of financial knowledge and how to understand the market.

I learned about consumer theory, producer theory, and market structures, as well as externalities. In addition, I got to see how pretty much everything in our lives can be connected to these microeconomics topics, which was very insightful. It gave me a new lens with which I can view things happening in the world. For example, schemes like buy 1 get 1 half off are price discrimination of firms trying to extract more profit from the consumer surplus, and bookstores putting your purchases into multiple bags utilize framing and the asymmetric value curve to make customers feel happier.

I developed an appreciation for microeconomics and economics in general. I gained valuable insights into rational decision making and I learned about important questions to consider when making life decisions.
Rational decision-making, Supply and Demand, market structures, consumer and producer theory
The concepts of Microeconomics and their applications in real life, including in the process of finding a job.
Intro level economics at the firm and individual level.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course moves very quickly. I understand that's part of the deal, but I wish a better notion of the day to day workload had been shown prior to the course's beginning.
Wish we didn't go over time but I understand why we did.
It was hard because it was so condensed.

The material was presented very well, and even though it was a condensed Summer course, the workload was segmented elegantly and the topics were digestible. The recorded lectures were very nice, and Tolga gave frequent examples and anecdotes which very very fun and engaging. I feel like the zoom live meetings could be split into 2 shorter sessions instead of 1 long one, because due to the large amount of material covered per session the classes often ran long, and sometimes it was a bit fatiguing to sit through without any breaks to get up and walk around.

Professor Koker and Dana both worked hard to make the course as engaging and productive as it could be, especially for an online summer course. I really enjoyed it, and I wouldn't change anything about it. I learned a lot.

We went through the material thoroughly and discussed applications in the real world. The live sessions could have moved a little faster since we were already assigned videos to go over prior to each class.

The excellent organization, devoted teaching staff and seamless execution of the class are strong strengths of the class. However, the only true weakness is the discrepancy that arises in what's taught during live lecture and tested in psets, although it is more than adequately covered in office hours (so go to every one!).

Strengths: Tolga's the best and made the summer class so much fun! Dana was also always super kind and supportive!
Weaknesses: Not enough time to fully grasp concepts.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you need a QR credit or a micro pre-rec over the summer, absolutely.
Yes since you get it over with instead of sitting through the class for extra weeks during the school year.
Yes. I think Tolga is a fantastic professor who is very knowledgeable and wants the best for his students.

For sure, the class is not only very valuable (as econ is a subject pretty much everyone should have some experience with) and can provide a helpful new worldview on current issues, but Tolga is also a great teacher and the class is very fun.
Absolutely! I'm glad to have more of an understanding of and appreciation for economics. Professor Koker and Dana both really know what they're talking about, and I learned a lot.
Yes, it has many applications in other fields and situations.

Overall a fantastic course to take in the summer. The materials are covered in a relevant and useful manner, with live lectures going over the foundations of concepts and their applications, while supplemented by recorded lectures that go through derivations and more in-depth descriptions. It has a more than manageable workload while not sacrificing on any key material for senior classes!
Yes! Whether you're an Econ major or not, you should take Econ 115!!

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: In intermediate micro.
I now understand the market and appreciate those who work in such field because it is difficult.

I will go on to take macroeconomics, but I also might look into getting an internship or doing research relating to applying AI/ML techniques to stocks which would definitely pull from some of the ideas we've covered in class.

I hope I will apply what we learned about rational decision making (opportunity cost, marginal revenue, etc.) to my own future decisions. Other concepts, like credibility signaling and how to present oneself when applying for jobs, will also be very useful. I'm grateful that we learned about price floors, rent controlled apartments, the war on drugs, the gender pay gap, recessions, inflation, monopolies, and many other important concepts from an economics perspective. I am appreciative of how tangibly applicable the knowledge and skills that I learned in this course are to life.
